intro: Loranthus jackii, commonly known as the Indian mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees, primarily in the family Rubiaceae. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while producing its own sugars through photosynthesis using the light it captures. The plant has small, leathery leaves and produces small, red berries that are an important food source for birds. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, including India and Southeast Asia. Its parasitic nature and unique ecological role make it an interesting subject in botanical studies.
